{{Infobox musical artist | name = John Németh | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1976}} | birth_place = [[Idaho]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | origin = | instrument = [[Harmonica]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Electric blues]], [[blue-eyed soul]] | occupation = [[List of harmonicists|Harmonicist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Early 1990s–present | label = [[Blind Pig Records|Blind Pig]], [[CD Baby]] | associated_acts = [[Junior Watson]]
[[Anson Funderburgh]] | website = {{URL|http://www.johnnemethblues.com/}} }} '''John Németh''' (born 1976) is an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] and [[Soul music|soul]] harmonicist, singer, and songwriter. He has recorded seven [[album]]s since 2002, having also backed [[Junior Watson]] and [[Anson Funderburgh]]. He has [[Opening act|opened]] for [[Robert Cray]], [[Keb' Mo']], and Earl Thomas.{{cite web|url=http://www.johnnemethblues.com/ |title=John Nemeth |publisher=Johnnemethblues.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}} [[Allmusic]] noted that he is a "vocalist with great range, ability, and soulfulness, Németh had also developed into a top-notch blues harmonica player..." In 2013 alone, he was nominated five times for a [[Blues Music Award]], making nine such nominations in total.{{cite web|url=http://www.sincitysoulandbluesrevival.com/artists/john-nemeth |title=John Nemeth |publisher=Sincitysoulandbluesrevival.com |date=2013-02-16 |accessdate=2013-03-26}} ==Biography== Németh was born in [[Idaho]], United States and grew up in [[Boise, Idaho|Boise]]. After singing at his local church, Németh played in local groups in his teenage years, and later formed Fat John & the 3 Slims with his friend Tom Moore. He toured and performed regularly working between five and seven nights a week for almost a decade.{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesinterviews/a/John-Nemeth-Interview-2010.htm |title=Interview with Blues Singer John Nemeth |publisher=Blues.about.com |date=2012-04-09 |accessdate=2013-03-26}} By 2000, Németh was supplying backing to [[Junior Watson]], and separately fronting his own band known as The Jacks. In 2002, he self-published the album, ''The Jack of Harps''. His debut solo effort, ''Come and Get It'', followed in 2004. The same year, Németh relocated to [[Oakland, California]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.blindpigrecords.com/index.cfm?section=artists&artistid=78 |title=Blind Pig Records |publisher=Blind Pig Records |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}}{{cite web|last=Hildebrand |first=Lee |url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/oakland/john-nemeth/Content?oid=3306121 |title=John Nemeth | CD Reviews |publisher=East Bay Express |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}} Gaining more experience, he temporarily replaced [[Sam Myers]] in [[Anson Funderburgh]]'s backing band in 2005 and 2006. In 2006, he signed a [[recording contract]] with [[Blind Pig Records]]. ''Magic Touch'', which was [[record producer|produced]] by Funderburgh and had Watson as a guest musician on several tracks, was issued in 2007. ''[[Living Blues]]'' stated "''Magic Touch'' gives hope that the blues will survive." The release saw Németh nominated for a Blues Music Award in the 'Best New Artist Debut' category. Németh also appeared on [[Elvin Bishop]]'s ''The Blues Roles On'' album (2008), which was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] in the [[Grammy Award for Best Traditional Blues Album|Best Traditional Blues Album]] category. Németh performed at the Blue Bear Live III concert on May 9, 2008 at the [[Great American Music Hall]], to benefit the [[Blue Bear School of Music]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bluebearmusic.org/bblive/index2008.html |title=Blue Bear Live III: A Youth Music Education Benefit - Blue Bear School of Music |publisher=Bluebearmusic.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-25}} Németh's next release, ''Love Me Tonight'' (2009), reached number 6 in the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Top Blues Albums Chart.{{cite web|author=John Nemeth |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-nemeth-mn0000484219/awards |title=John Nemeth - Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}} Németh's fourth solo release, ''Name the Day!'', was released in 2010. It equalled the achievement of ''Love Me Tonight'' by peaking at number 6 in the ''Billboard'' Top Blues Albums Chart. ''Blues Live'' was recorded in February 2012 at three venues in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], and included guitar contributions from [[Christoffer Andersen|Kid Andersen]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/johnnemeth2 |title=John Nemeth | Blues Live | CD Baby Music Store |publisher=Cdbaby.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}} ''Soul Live'' was released in September 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/soul-live-mw0002440740/releases |title=Soul Live - John Nemeth : Releases |publisher=AllMusic |date=2012-09-07 |accessdate=2013-03-26}} In December 2012, Németh appeared at the PowerHouse Pub in [[Folsom, California]].{{cite web|url=http://events.sacbee.com/folsom_ca/events/show/294214385-john-nemeth |title=John Nemeth at PowerHouse Pub - Sacramento Bee |publisher=Events.sacbee.com |date=2012-12-02 |accessdate=2013-03-26}} The following February, he performed in his home town of Boise.{{cite web|last=Morgan |first=Tara |url=http://www.boiseweekly.com/boise/john-nemeth-returns-to-boise/Content?oid=2814910 |title=John Nemeth Returns to Boise | Saturday, February 16, 2013 at Egyptian Theatre | Listen Here |publisher=Boise Weekly |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}} In 2013, Németh was nominated in five categories for a Blues Music Award. These included 'B.B. King Entertainer', 'Contemporary Blues Album', 'Instrumentalist - Harmonica', 'Soul Blues Album', and 'Soul Blues Male Artist'.{{cite web|url=https://blues.org/#ref=bluesmusicawards_nominees|title=Blues Music Awards Nominees 2013 - 34th Blues Music Awards|publisher=Blues.org|accessdate=2013-03-26}} Németh is due to perform at the Great Lakes Blues Society in April; the Simi Valley Cajun & Blues Music Festival in May; and the Jackson Rhythm and Blues Festival in August 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.songkick.com/artists/2361516-john-nemeth |title=John Németh Tour Dates 2013 — John Németh Concert Dates and Tickets |publisher=Songkick |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}} He relocated to [[Memphis, Tennessee]] in early 2013, and has stated that [[the Bo-Keys]] will back him on his next recording.{{cite web|last=Deeds |first=Michael |url=http://www.idahostatesman.com/2013/02/10/2446113/coming-to-boise-john-nemeth-louis.html |title=Michael Deeds: John Nemeth, Louis CK, Alan Jackson are coming to Boise | Michael Deeds |publisher=Idahostatesman.com |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}} In 2014, he won a Blues Music Award in the 'Soul Blues Male Artist of the Year' category.{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}} Németh is sponsored by [[Hohner]]. ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year || Title || Record label |- | 2002 || ''The Jack of Harps''{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-jack-of-harps-mw0000497105/releases |title=The Jack of Harps - John Nemeth and the Jacks : Releases |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-03-26}}
